Award.AwardTitle: DMREF/Collaborative Research: Collaboration to Accelerate the Discovery of New Alloys for Additive Manufacturing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical: Recently, there has been significant interest in additive manufacturing, also known as 3-D printing. While there have been many efforts aimed at exploring the geometric design space, thus enabling innovative components, such efforts invariably use legacy materials (e.g., Ti-6Al-4V) that were designed and optimized decades ago for conventional manufacturing approaches. When the material is not part of the design strategy, there is both an intrinsic risk and an opportunity lost. With respect to risk, such legacy materials may exhibit properties that are inferior to the same material prepared using conventional approaches. For example, when Ti-6-4 is arbitrarily selected for additive manufacturing processes, the resultant material exhibits properties that vary according to both testing direction and spatial location. With respect to the lost opportunity, there are unique characteristics of the additive manufacturing processes, such as very high solidification rates, that can result in superior properties for the right materials. Thus, there is a need to design new materials that leverage the unique characteristics of additive manufacturing processes to achieve a balance of properties that exceeds what is currently possible when legacy materials are used. The titanium alloys developed under this Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) program, as well as the general framework of accelerated alloy development, will be disseminated through a series of industry dissemination workshops. This dissemination will impact a wide range of economic sectors, including, for example, aerospace, automotive, and biomedical.

Technical: This project is directed toward the design of a modern creep-resistant beta-titanium alloy to be produced via additive manufacturing. This will be achieved by integrating high-throughput combinatorial materials science, state-of-the-art materials characterization, computational materials science, and data-science. The project seeks to: (1) discover and model the fundamental interrelationship between the far-from equilibrium conditions of additive manufacturing processes and materials composition on the resulting microstructure and properties; (2) fully describe the materials composition and structure using multi-dimensional, multi-spatial, and multi-spectral approaches; (3) determine, via powerful data science approaches, hidden correlations (e.g., mechanisms) between composition, structure, and properties as assessed using both computational and experimental techniques; (4) validate the mechanisms via computational modeling and critical experimentation; and (5) design, as a multi-university team, a new material for additive manufacturing processes. Along the way, the team will develop both an ontology and data science standards so that the information can be shared easily amongst the four universities during the program and disseminated more broadly at the conclusion of the effort.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Additive manufacturing (AM), also known as 3D printing, is becoming a critical technology in many industries, with additively-manufactured parts appearing in a wide range of technologies, from aircraft to medical devices. In particular, direct metal deposition processes, such as Laser Engineered Net Shaping (LENS?), have the ability to construct near net shape parts, open cellular structures, compositionally graded parts, and parts with improved mechanical properties over those manufactured via traditional methods such as casting and forging. To utilize additive processes to their full potential, it is imperative that the relationships between the manufacturing process and the properties of the manufactured part are understood. The overall goal of our project was to link the processing of metallic alloys via additive manufacturing to characterization of the microstructures in the manufactured materials to characterization of the properties of the materials, yielding a rich database of information that could guide the development of computational models, which in turn could inform and guide the experimental efforts.  The main systems of interest in the program were alloys of titanium, given their many critical applications. 

 The part of the program described in this report was focused on the development of new computational tools to predict the final microstructures of an additively manufactured metallic alloy, specifically binary alloys of titanium. Our focus was on the LENS? process, in which streams of metallic powders are combined and melted in a strong laser and then deposited on a growing part. The challenge is that the solidification process is extremely complicated, involving a wide range of physical phenomena.  A successful model of the entire AM process must include all significant aspects of those phenomena, especially fluid flow, heat flow, diffusion and solidification. However, for the modeling to be useful for our industrial colleagues, the computations must be fast enough to yield rapid results. Our strategy was to not rely on massive computing, but to develop somewhat simple models that capture the physical processes well enough to yield useful, if not perfect predictions, all based on a type of modeling called Cellular Automata (CA). 

We coupled a Lattice Boltzmann (LB) method for fluid flow, heat flow and solute transport with a cellular automata to describe the solidification process. The LB method was chosen because couples the phenomena and describes the interaction of the fluid with the complex shapes of the growing solid.  The solidification is described with a CA that incorporates the phase diagram of the system, the local interface temperature (from the macroscale temperature field), and so on. The CA approach has fast computational speed and known success in a wide range of solidification problems. Even so, the calculations were sufficiently computationally intensive that, in keeping with our goal of avoiding intensive computation when possible, we used a variety of levels of approximation throughout the project.

In this project we developed a suite of computational models that enable us to examine in detail many aspects of the solidification process of binary alloys under the conditions found in additive manufacturing. Our applications ranged from modeling details of dendritic growth in two dimensions, in which dendrite arm spacings were directly compared with experiment, to predictions of the transition between columnar solidification to equiaxed grains in three dimensions as a function of alloy content and thermal conditions. Using the complete suite of models, including heat, fluid, and solute flow along with the solidification, we can now predict how changes in parameters such as the speed and/or direction of the laser affects the solidification microstructure. Being able to do detailed comparison of these results with experiments is problematic, however, in large part because the exact thermal and fluid conditions of the experiments are generally not known.  That said, when we could make such comparisons, our results were found to be, at best, quantitatively and, at worst, qualitatively accurate, and thus sufficient for guiding future experimental efforts.

 


Last Modified: 09/07/2020
Modified by: Richard A Lesar

Images (1 of )
  • The lines show the speed of solidification versus undercooling in Ti-Mo alloys. The blue area shows where nucleation could occur. As Mo concentration increases, nucleated grains are more likely to nucleate at smaller velocities, leading to the observed columnar to equiaxed transition.
    Matthew R. Rolchigo
    Richard A Lesar
    Solidification in Ti-Mo alloys
  • Microstructure results for the solidification of melt pools formed at three beam scan velocities. The more elongated melt pools formed at faster scan speed lead to flatter melt pools and more growth from the melt pool bottom, along with faster solidification allowing more nucleation to occur.
    Matthew R. Rolchigo
    Copyrighted
    Richard A Lesar
    Effects of laser velocity on microsturcture.
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Additive manufacturing (AM), also known as 3D printing, is becoming a critical technology in many industries, with additively-manufactured parts appearing in a wide range of technologies, from aircraft to medical devices. In particular, direct metal deposition processes, such as Laser Engineered Net Shaping (LENS?), have the ability to construct near net shape parts, open cellular structures, compositionally graded parts, and parts with improved mechanical properties over those manufactured via traditional methods such as casting and forging. To utilize additive processes to their full potential, it is imperative that the relationships between the manufacturing process and the properties of the manufactured part are understood. The overall goal of our project was to link the processing of metallic alloys via additive manufacturing to characterization of the microstructures in the manufactured materials to characterization of the properties of the materials, yielding a rich database of information that could guide the development of computational models, which in turn could inform and guide the experimental efforts. The main systems of interest in the program were alloys of titanium, given their many critical applications. The part of the program described in this report was focused on the development of new computational tools to predict the final microstructures of an additively manufactured metallic alloy, specifically binary alloys of titanium. Our focus was on the LENS? process, in which streams of metallic powders are combined and melted in a strong laser and then deposited on a growing part. The challenge is that the solidification process is extremely complicated, involving a wide range of physical phenomena. A successful model of the entire AM process must include all significant aspects of those phenomena, especially fluid flow, heat flow, diffusion and solidification.
